element_texts.text:
Cantonment Reno 
Decr 2d 1896
Reveille as 5.30. Broke camp at 7.20. Ice hardly strong enough
so I built a bridge of logs & poles over it for the men to pass over—.
Very cold morning — & the wounded?
got off late. I remained by my camp fire- until 8.30. Came direct
while the road was very round about.
Killed two Sage Grouse with rifle—
Wounded another- Ought to have 
got more. Long & hard march -
arrived 4 pm-  Cmd half an 
hour later- Camped on
the old ground. No mail.

Crazy Horse napping - & if we do --- Very bad news from the States -- Rioting & fighting -- Politicians will rule or run

 To bed very early. Saw Pollock for a moment & went for him on the coal question - Got a quart of whiskey as a great favor from Trader's store. Fortunately for the Comd he is out of that action -- Will probably remain here tomorrow -- Men did well on the march today - & I am well pleased with my Comd.
 Distance 28 miles --

unclear train unclear and in unclear while waiting for wagons - found out where we are going on Belle Fourche south of unclear creek - on which at last accounts Crazy Horse was encamped.  Find only 70,000 pounds? forage here a little over two days supply - & that alone assures us against any further success. Our animals must break down in a week or ten days without forage.

 We will however try it any way. It is barely possible. We may by this detour catch

me to get my Comd off as early as possible for Buffalo Springs -- I was disgusted, but there is no use in being so with Crook's orders. He really does not know ahead what he intends to do. Makes up his mind at the last moment & then acts at once -- expecting everybody else to do the same.

 He has nothing to do but make up his mind. I have to take care of my men - 
  I had clothing to draw & other things to attend to. Had the General at 8:30

Buffalo Springs
Dry Fork of Powder R.
Decr 3rd 1876
Genl Crook told me last night that we would probably remain at Reno today. At all events would not start before 11 or 12 O clk. I therefore ordered reveille at 6.30 & breakfast at 7.30. I was lying in my bed about 7 waiting for my man to bring water when an orderly came to the tent door to say that the Genl wished

affairs on the new departure.

 I leave a Lieut & 30 men here. It is to be our depot unclear of supplies. I send in unclear accounts to Fort Fetterman -- Have organized a unclear party. Tomorro we strike out for ourselves on an untried route -- across to the head of the Belle Fourche & then down that stream -- Don't expect we will do any thing -- Are now short of forage -- 10 days ½ forage on hand & ground covered with snow. Shoshone Indians left us at Reno & are going

& got my men off a little after 9:30. I started about an hour after. It was a unclear warm day. The ground unclear with melting snow. unclear got tired & I got very tired on the short march. I was more tired than I was yesterday on the very long one. The Comd got into Camp about 5 pm

   Wrote a short letter to Tooty -- to send by Courier who left at sun set. Issued a special order regulating

Buffalo Springs
Decr 4th 76.
Got up late this am with the expectation of getting off about 11.30. Had all my details made & every thing ready for a start. About 10 O'clk went over to see the Genl & was informed that we would not move today. Supposed it due to arrival of train with forage, but when I went over this afternoon to see if we started early tomorro he informed me that we would not move so long as it

directly back to their country about Ft Bridger. Have Sioux, Arrapahoes & Pawnees with us yet -- Genl killed a new kind of snow bird today-- very rich colors. He gave me the telegram of political news. 

 Bad situation. I wish we could be ordered in -- If there is to be trouble, I'd like to be on hand. Dr. Ousley leaves us here -- paid me his mess bill -- $20. Lake Cummings at Trees? after tomorro --
 Distance 14 miles -- Bad Camp water & grass miserable

matter where secrecy can be of no sort of service — I am sorry to say that I do not believe he has any definite?? plan or expectation. He proposes to go a certain distance in a certain direction hoping like Mr Macawber that something may turn up, but his actions convince me that he Either has no plan, or that it is very idly made. For instance he sent off from Crazy Woman, a lot of Indians

threatens to storm. That the Indians said a severe storm was coming up & he did not wish it to catch us on the divide? without wood for the men or shelter for animals. He said moreover that he did not mind the delay as we had plenty of time to do what we have to do — What that is not a soul knows except himself. & I must say it is extremely exasperating to have so very much secrecy about a

work on, is a problem for a Brig Genl— I can't solve it —  There is nothing of news today. Weeting? came on from Reno & was in camp for an hour or two. He is ordered to take McKinney's body to Cheyenne. & afterwards has 2 months leave of absence — Campbell came to my tent at night and asked me for two hours — Taking Sunday unclear. Must off at lark. "It's a long leave &c &c" —

to procure more recruits from the  Agencies — It will take those Indians at least 8 days to get to the agency — & not less than 10 ten days more will be required for those recruits to get to the Little Missouri where they are to meet up — We start from here when this storm is over with rations to the 20th Decr How the recruits are to do us any good, with so small a march to

Soon after breakfast Crook and Mackenzie came to my tent both in fine unclear. And orderly soon after came over with a copy of Sheridan's & Sherman's telegrams congratulating C & M on that affair with the Cheyennes — Mac. was very like himself under the praises of his superiors & was gen'ly?-jolly. 

After he went off I boned? Crook on the situation — I told him that I did not ask out of mere curiosity

Buffalo Springs
Decr 5th 1876
The wind blew terribly in the night & I had some anxiety for my tent but it stood the pressure all right. I slept well though I was annoyed somewhat at the continued flapping of of the fly. After I got up I had it sewed fast to the tent & there is no more flap. We do not move today & the weather was given as reason. It was too unclear —

continue down that to its junction with Big Powder. 

From there as a center the Indians will radiate in all directions. If they find a village we will go for it on packmules. If not we will return. I carefully Estimated the distances with him. "It will take" I said "about ten days for the Comd to reach that point. Allow two days for the Indians to unclear & it will be say the 18th of this month

but that if there was no reason for secrecy I wanted to know what were his plans for the next thirty days. To my surprise & pleasure he said there was no secrecy at all & that he would tell me all I wanted to know. I got the maps & went for him with a lot of questions. We are to march by Pumpkin Buttes to the Belle Fourche & go down that stream to its forks. Then strike across to Little Powder river &

28th of this month & to Ft Fetterman by 31.st If we should strike Indians while on pack mule scout any where within two or three days march of the mouth of Tongue River, we will go in there & get some rations. If we dont find a village we will come back without the pack mule scout. 

He wishes to be very careful of the men & animals. He has no trouble about rations only about forage

before we commence our pack mule march. Suppose that to last ten days. We will get back to our wagons by the 28th. With the utmost expedition we cannot get back to this camp under 6 days — or by 3d Jan.y. We have rations only to the 31. Dec. Now how can you manage it?" —He said, I want to be back to this Camp by the

talk to him is that Rockwell the Comy has been ordered to get 3 to 5 days rations here by the time we get back. 

After he left Mackenzie came in & wanted to know all Crook had told me. I told the story & we went over the maps together. Mac found that from the forks of Belle Fourche direct by Camp Jenney? to Camp Robinson, it is only from 7 to 8 days travel

We are staying here not so much on account of the storm but to give the Indians sent to the agency, time to get the recruits & meet us on Powder River. He asked me many questions about the country between the forks of Belle Fourche & Camp Jenney?. It is horrible no wood, grass, or drinkable water & I told him so, but this desert is only 60 miles across. One result of my

that portion of the Comd which goes to the R.R. to strike it at siding over? the Agency, as to return this way, So it is possible even probable that we will return that way, if on our return to forks of Belle Fourche we have rations for that trip

Those forks are as I said 8 days from Camp Robinson but only 3 from here & here we get more rations, but

while from the same point around this way & by Fort Fetterman & Laramie it is 17 or 18 days. He seized the point at once & said that he would urge Crook to let him & all the Comd bound for the Agency go across that way. He would rather risk the desert of 60 miles if by doing so he could cut off 10 days march. 

It is about as unclear for

The water here & there is only a small quantity- is very alkaline & really unfit for drinking. Most of us are using melted snow — It is not very good & is not satisfying but it is far better than the springs.

There is no wind tonight & it is clear & beautiful. Burke & Schuyler came over to see us this afternoon. Egan is sick.

no more forage. I ordered unclear to be made & left here with the men to be left. Beef cattle were sent for tonight to Reno. They will be up tomorro. We will remain here tomorro, though the storm appears over — a nice game of whist in the evening. I feel a great deal better since Crook unburdened himself

hurried off his unclear. The general? sounded at 8.45 & by a little after 9 I started. The Comd got off about 10. The route followed the divide between the branches of the Dry Fork & is crooked in the extreme. I have made a map of the march & country on the last page of this book. The ravines are almost impassable & we were fortunate to get over them without breaking something.

By a greater detour to the east we might have

Brouard? Springs
South of East End Pumpkin Bte
Decr 6, 1876
Slept like a log?. While dressing an orderly came with "the Genls compliments & the Comd will move at 12 m." Found on going out that the mules had not been turned out to graze & after breakfast I went over to see the Genl & asked if I might break camp at once as that would give the mules time to graze in the afternoon. 

He not only consented but

Powder or Crazy Woman. 

There is also very good & abundant grass, but no wood. Below us the Indians got some wood, & but that we brought plenty with us. I guess we would have found some. I got into a most comfortable & sheltered nook. The day has been lovely, & the march an interesting one, over the crookedest road in America. Only a few crossings but they were bad. Pioneers? did well. 
Distance about 11 miles.
Pumpkin Buttes near us North.

avoided all. We are however following a wagon trail. It is called the Montana Trail & has been used by miners coming from Montana to Blk Hills. 

At 2.30 pm after a long detour to the South East, we suddenly turned to the North & soon after came to camp in a ravine running a little north of west in which was a spring of water deep & clear & only slightly alkaline. much better than any we have had for some time past. Better even than

bugles sounded & I got up. Had breakfast & mounted my horse by daylight. in fact it was too dark to see the track of the pioneer wagon — so I had to go & hunt the road.

Had not gone a quarter of a mile before I found a Pawnee wagon overturned, a precursor of what was in store for us. Got started at 10 minutes to 7. am. Went directly north & after a little over a mile came to Clark & the pioneer wagon turned around & at

Belle Fourche Springs
Decr 7th 1876
Reveille at 5.30. Slept badly, due somewhat to coffee, somewhat to loose mules.
Smith & Cook amused themselves by quarrelling - d _ uy? each other in the middle of the night. Kistler my special man made my fire about 4.30 am & called me to breakfast by 5. I abused him & tried to sleep, but soon the

fair, but there was no telling what was ahead. The road was to our left rear. 

I put in my oar, by saying that twas no weather for trying experiments. so he gave the order for the wagons to turn back & take the road. We were then at the east end of Pumpkin Butte. The road ran west to the west of the Butte then turned north. The Genl with his Hd Qr Gd struck across country to go around the Butte to the South. I felt equal to the

a halt. The guide, who had left the road saying that he knew a much better route, had confessed himself lost. & had started out to assure himself of his position. I forgot to say that when I got up it was snowing fast & at this time a dense cloud over hung every thing so we could hardly see Pumpkin Butte. 
Genl Crook came up just then & wanted to know what was the matter. Clark explained. The Genl was non-plussed. The route before us looked

man on my right who I thought was he. I sent my orderly after him & presently he beconed - I went to him & found him on the brink of a nasty chasm 50 to 60 feet deep, & so steep that a man could not cross. By going to the East he found an old trail & we managed to get over one branch of the chasm, & were then obliged to go along a narrow back bone between the two, something scarcely three feet wide, & with great pieces ready to tumble off on each side into the abyss.

task of piloting my Comd & struck to the north of the Butte, across country. Just in front of where the wagons turned back was a nasty arroyo, which we crossed & started on a course. When we had gone about a mile Frank Grouard the guide (not the one who got lost) overtook me. He said that it was all plain sailing in front & went ahead. In a short time I saw a

deer, running across my front about 150 yards off. 

I was terribly bundled up, but I jumped off my horse & got out a couple of cartridges. By this time the deer had seen the Citizen ahead, & dashing into the ravine, ran almost directly towards me. I waited until he was about 60 yds off & fired. He fell, but jumped up again. Again I fired & he laid down in the ravine. I went up and cut his throat.
My first shot had broken

I rode over this trail, but I confess to certain nervous tremors. The other Offs walked over & led their horses. Men got over all right. After passing this place we had no trouble — though in coming down into the arroyos of the Belle Fourche, we had to cross two or three nasty places.

While crossing the last one I heard many shots & yells, & while going up the bank a Citizen dashed past me, his horse at a run. When I got on top, I saw a Black tailed

pm, & waited until near dark before a single wagon got up. Then came Genl C's Hdqr wagon, & soon after mine. It is now after 9. pm, & some of the Company wagons are not in yet.
Gave Wheaton & Pollock a supper, as their wagons are not in. After my supper about 8. pm I went over to Genl C. to remonstrate with him on the bad management of the Trains. He had gone to bed, so I pitched

one hind leg & gone through the other, almost spoiling both hams. However he has lots of good meat on him besides legs. 

In a few hundred yards after this we struck the road. Genl C. had passed but the train was nowhere to be seen. From this point the road runs nearly north & is very good, except an occasional bad ravine.
We got to camp at 3

A venison ham is the thigh meat from the hind leg of a deer

We expect tomorro to strike wood water & grass, & from what Rockwell the Comy tells me today there is another change in Gen. C's programme We are to lay over after tomorro for four days, to send back for more unclear stores -

 However good a soldier Crook may be, he has no administrative ability whatever. He well knows that this part of the expedition must be a failure if for no other

with Fury the Qr Mr. . He made so many promises of improvement that I could not scold much. The fact is the mules are played out.

 They are kept in harness from daylight till dark - then tied to a wagon pole until daylight again. Not one has been curried or any other care taken of him since we started & they are expected to do all the work on half forage of grain.

& Indian ponies are giving out every day, & by the time we reach the mouth of little Powder it will be a miracle if more than half of us do not have to walk back. yet he pushes on. I would not say it out loud, but I think he is pushing on now simply from vanity - It will look well to go on, no matter at what cost of life or property. He will come to great grief some day from this trait of character -

reason, because we cannot transport our supplies. His train is in wretched condition yet he does nothing to get or keep it in order. He might be a cavalry man for his carelessness  of his means of transportation. Mules are the very first element of success in such an Expedition as this - yet he seems to care nothing whatever for his mules -- The cavy horses

Sent him word to come in - I must take care of my men - even if we lose some stock -

 Distance today 20 miles - good water standing in holes - no wood - grass very poor - plenty of sage brush for both fuel & forage - Terribly bad day - snow sleet & wind - all day --

There seems to be plenty of small game here, rabbits & sage grouse - but I had no time to hunt & no shotgun. The pioneers killed 2 antelope & an Officer 1 today . The Indians also killed some game - Had a good supper Wrote my journal - Smith Offr Day - sent in for permission to come in -
Is 3½ miles out, & several teams are broken down.

or six. I was in rear taking it easy & got no shot, except at a Jack rabbit which I killed - Our mules are nearly played out having to work from daylight until after dark, & then are tied up to the tongue of a wagon - When I got to the Camping place, Crook wanted me to go a mile & a half beyond - I told him that my wagons could not make it before dark

Belle Fourche
Decr 8, 1876
Reveille at 6:30 to give to my belated travellers a chance to rest. Started 8 am. Very cold with a little snow -

Road for ten miles very good then crossed a lot of broken country with bad ravines --
A great deal of game killed today principally antelope & by the Indians, though Officers & men got five

condition of their lack of food, of their constant work & no care. That by his order I had nothing to do with them & could not give an order to a teamster. 

He said he knew the condition of the animals, that he had a certain problem to work out & had to do the best he could with his materials.
I could'nt tell him so, of course, but he does not do the best with his

He was rather cross & said that my teams were broken down hauling wood & that Fury had ordered a lot of wood thrown off. I told him I had ordered no wood to be carried, & that my qrmr had not reported any violation of the order - etc. etc. 
After I had selected & got my men into Camp I went over to see him & talked quite freely on the whole question - told him their

is ever curried, some of them are cruelly beaten, they get no grazing because he is too tender with his teamsters to make them go on herd. Altogether the transportation of this expedition is the very worst managed I have ever seen, & if for no other reason the expn must be a failure.

I find there is no sort of use in talking to Crook & it really seems sometimes as if he expected a

materials. He takes no sort of care of his transportation. Fury has impressed him with the idea that he is a wonderfully good Qr. Mr. while the fact is he is as poor an one as I ever saw. He is no doubt a good in door Qrmr but he leaves the whole management of his train to understrappers, who neglect it entirely. No mule

Had a long talk with Crook & Frank Grouard as to the best route to the Rail Road. Frank says he can take us to Fort Laramie by a good route in 8 days. I am pretty sure we will return by Black Hills. There is some talk of sending back for more rations, but Crook said nothing about it --

We have now only about 10 days, & must send back or go in to Ft Laramie very soon. 

Camped in 4 in. snow

failure, & intended to lay the blame on the failure of his means of transpn.

We might just as well go in now, but his pride will make him kill a few hundred animals first. 
Wagons got into camp just at dark. Poor Camp. Very little wood, no grass & water alkaline & bad.
Distance 18 miles, road rough —

The hills on each side are a curious combination of red sand stone & bad land formation & there is no getting over them. The wagons had to keep the bottom where there is any, & struggle over the span of hills as best they could. The difficulty was that we had to cross the Belle Fourche many times. It is a nasty gulch with banks from 20 to 30 feet

Belle Fourche 
Decr 9th 1876
Reveille at 6.30. Started 8 am. This march is only to find a good camp. Marched down the Belle Fourche. 1½ miles below our camp of last night came in the large fork from the South East. Marked on the maps. The route was as bad as could be --

management of affairs but have finally concluded that I can do no sort of good by quarrelling. I am not responsible, & there is no sense in making enemies. I can stand it as long as they can — so "let her rip" — I shall say nothing more. 

Soon after my arrival orders for details came pouring in, so I knew that something was up. Must over to HQ Qrs at night. Saw Bourke

high. Getting down & up these banks was work indeed. We came only 5 miles, yet some of the wagons did not get in until after dark. My Command got to Camp before 11 Oclk but all my wagons were not in until near 3. pm. My own were among the last. Had half a row? with Fury about the

Bourke told me that if the train sent in did not find at Buffalo Springs the train sent to Fetterman for supplies, a courier & an Indian would go on towards Fetterman, meet the train & take it across country towards Inyan Kara

Distance today 5 miles. Good Camp, plenty of wood & water, but grass is very scarce --

& got orders to send one Compy to escort a train back to our Depot at Buffalo Springs to bring up all the supplies & troops left there.

I detailed? Capt Jordan of 9th with his Compy.
From what I can hear it seems likely that we will strike across to the Black Hills from here. Indeed it is almost sure that such is now the intention.

evening, so I got out one of Fred's? old novels — Shirley — & read until late. I dont think much of it, a good many brilliant thoughts, but the people are all unnatural. I have often tried to read it before, but as often failed. 

All quiet. Jordan left early this morning, before I was up. Didn't see him. Sent all our stock out grazing. Lovely day, warm & balmy though the morning was cool.
Nothing new.

Belle Fourche
Decr 10, 76.
Up late at about 7 am as we do not move today. Went over to see the Genl but he had gone out somewhere. Passed a very quiet day. In afternoon had my Hdqr tents moved up on the plateau as the bottom which I first selected is from the warm weather & melted snow a mass of sticky mud.

It got very hum drum in

but was answered by one of the men -(two had come in) assuring me that he was telling the truth. He was in his stocking feet & had no coat, & the other tho' he had shoes had neither coat or pants, & both were shivering with cold & fright. They had come in this style? five miles. I bade the Off Day take them to Genl Crook, & still incredulous went to sleep again.

Belle Fourche
Decr 11, 1876.
Was waked up about 2 am by the Off Day, who informed me that a party of miners returning from the Black Hills to Montana & which passed us yesterday about 1 pm going towards Reno, had been attacked by Indians at our Camp of 9th. Their stock & everything taken from them — had just come in asking assistance. I refused to believe the report

stole noiselessly into their camp & opened fire on the sleeping forms. All sprung to their feet & made off into the darkness except one. By daylight all had got into this camp except that one. The party sent out to assist found the body of that one stark & cold. He had had his leg broken by a shot, & the Indians had then seized an axe & split his head open He was still lying where he

The Genl sent out early this morning & found the story only too true. There were eleven men. They were travelling with two light wagons, one drawn by 4 horses, the other by 4 oxen. They camped 5 miles above us, turned out their stock, made a big fire, cooked their supper & all turned in not a single man being left as guard or sentinel. About 1 am 5 Indians (as appears from the Trail)

& a party of Arrapahoes sent on the trail. They can never catch the rascals I doubt —

There are several opinions as to what Indians did this for so small a party — very daring deed. My opinion was that it is a party of Agency Indians who have been following these miners from the Black Hills, for this same party of miners was attacked thirty miles North East of here four days ago & six ponies taken

had gone to bed, not having been able to move after the shot. The Indians had taken the horses & cattle, all the ammunition they could find & a few articles of little value. They knew evidently that we were near for they wasted no time but started South at once. Our Indians after a careful examination of every thing around, came in and reported. A party was sent out to bury the dead man

moccasin in the confusion of the fight & not being able to find it in the dark left it. It was nothing but a piece of raw buffalo hide which had been put over the foot & tied around at the ancle. I have very little confidence in such signs as indicating tribes, as all Indians after committing a depredation or outrage leave, if they can, some distinctive article belonging to another

from them — As the hostiles were on foot & seemed to come from the South, the friendly Indians are of the opinion that the daring rascals are Cheyennes, of the very band we so injured on 25th ult, & who are now following us in the hope of revenge on small parties, stragglers &c.

This view is somewhat confirmed by the fact that one of the hostiles lost his

Ult refers to the preceding month.

phase? of character of the large majority of the men who risk their lives on the frontier mining, trapping or prospecting. They are brave to imbecility or stupid beyond expression. 

A few men, possibly comparative strangers to each other, band together & agree to go to this or that place. Without apparently the slightest concern, they plunge into unknown wildernesses & through countries swarming with treacherous & deadly Indians.

tribe so as to shift if possible the suspicion from themselves. 

But in this case it seems possible the Cheyennes are the rascals. Their being on foot is one evidence that way, their coming from the south on our trail another, & the mockasin another since buffalo are very scarce out of the mountains at present & there being none toward the Agencies. The fate of this man & the party illustrates a peculiar

we not here by the merest chance for them, not one would likely escape alive. 

I once when travelling with a train & troops, came on the high wide prairie, suddenly on the form of a man, lying on his stomach & sleeping profoundly. He was at least 30 miles from any road & in a very dangerous country. I called to him loudly. He sat up & gazed stupidly for a moment or two then smiled & seemed

They travel without order & without care. If while hunting one should discover Indians, he rushes back to his party which flees if it can, or fights with courage & tenacity if necessary. Arrived at a Camping place they turn out their stock, get supper & go to bed as unconcerned as if no danger were around them. If jumped they have no chance & lose all, &, as in this case, were

arms, no bedding, & not a thing to eat, yet was unconcernedly going to certain death had I not found him gave him to eat & told him where to go. Another wonderful peculiarity of these adventurers is that they plunge into any wilderness, undertake any journey without map or compass & without the slightest knowledge of the geography of the country over which they are to travel. It would seem

relieved. "Where do you belong" I asked. "I come from Iowa" he answered. "What are you doing here" I demanded very peremptorily. "Oh I am looking for work" he said quietly. I thought at first that he was a lunatic, but further questioning satisfied me that he was only an ordinary plains lunatic, that is one who feared no danger because he saw none. This man had no

long bereft, self bereft, of all ties of blood or kindred. They disappear from one section. If they turn up in another all right. If not, there are no anxious friends to wonder why, or to institute inquiries. They disappear & that is the last of them. The how, the why & the wherefore are never known, because never inquired into. The poor victim of last

that Providence has special charge of these people as of children, idiots & drunkards, but this is only partially so. Many parties get through all right as by a miracle. Them we hear of & wonder at. We never hear of the great number of parties that dont get through, & which disappear & leave no sign. The great majority of these men are outcasts & vagabonds

looks over a package of letters. To me this mail was indeed a blessing. Two nice letters from Father & Mother, assuring me that all my loved ones south are well. Two from Kate Chambliss loving & kind & grateful. It is a true pleasure to have it our power to do good to such a woman as Kate. She fights her hard battle of life so nobly & so well. She is

night was buried where he lay, & I doubt if anyone in this camp even knows his name.

About 12 m an orderly came over from Hdqrs & handed me a little mail for my Command. One living all his life surrounded with the Comforts & Conveniences of Civilization cannot realize? the feeling with which a wanderer in the wilderness

off until next year. She has lent the money to Mr Parker at 8 per ct — a very good disposition of it as the interest will help her. 

Two letters from Blackmore noble friend, who flatters me on my book, & tells me it is out Novr 2d & that I will be proud of it. One long letter from Fred, written in

so truly a true woman, so economical, so proud so managing, so self reliant so independent, so grateful & so loving, that I wish constantly I could do for her a great deal more than I can ever hope to do. 

She had received the $300 I sent her to buy a part of her Father's homestead but the sale was put

President. I hope & trust all this political warfare may end without bloodshed & that when we return we will find all settled & peaceful. It is bad enough to fight Indians. I hope brothers hands will not again imbrue themselves with brothers blood. 

And order came this pm for one of my Battalions to march tomorro. We

very good style but abominable hand. He is well studying hard & is in good spirits— & last & best one from Tooty, loving & kind full of fear for my safety & hope of my distinction inconsistent but womanly. A most satisfactory & delightful mail. There is no news — & as yet no

Belle Fourche
Decr 12. 76
Reveille at 6.30. Got off at 8 - with General Hdqrs & the Arty Batn The Infy were left behind there being not enough wagons - 
Stopped for half an hour with Mackenzie - & had a pleasant visit - Marched only about 5 miles west into Camp. The Creek is here a running stream & full of beaver - a large

go down the creek a few miles hunting a better camp I take the Artillery Battalion that having but 4 Comps. 

The water is bad here & the snow which we have been melting for drinking purposes is fast disappearing The day has been warm balmy & beautiful. Such winter campaigns as this we can stand. But I fear me we will pay for it soundly.

Belle Fourche
Decr 13. 76
Got up at usual time & had a good breakfast - 
Some of my staff were very anxious to route out some beavers which have built a large dam & house just opposite where we are encamped & came to me for assistance in the performance. Met with them & gave advice -

dam & house is directly in front of us - Road generally good but there are many bad ravines to cross - Our wagons unloaded & returned at once to bring up the Infy which will be here tomorro am - Disagreeable nasty night - snow sleet & wind - played whist with Campbell against Smith & Clark Got beaten the long rub - 
Campbell don't know the game
Distance 5 miles

opening & found no beaver -
The cute little rascals had evacuated the premises yesterday. The noise around & above them showing them that they "were in danger -
They had a good sized house & the bedroom was sufficiently large for a man to lie in comfortably - 
It was about 4 by 6 feet with a ceiling about 3 feet high. I also

The dam was first cut so as to let the water off sufficiently to enable us to find the entrance to the house. After an hour or two this was accomplished - 
The entrance was found & stopped up & they went to breaking into the house, a most tedious labor -
However after an hour of hard work they got an

some spies whom he sent into the hostile camp. He will not take any risks of roaming about scouting the country with this command.
If he can find the hostile camp & it is within reach he will strike it. If he can not find it, or if it is too far away he will go in.
I think he takes a very sensible view of all the facts & I expect I have done him injustice in

tried to fish through the ice but either there are no fish or they were frightened by the noise around them & the rush & rapid fall of the water - Got no bite
Some time after I got back to my tent. Genl Crook came in. He was in a most amiable humor & talked very freely & pleasantly. He expects the Sioux scouts every day now & also

Belle Fourche
Decr 14, 1876
Thursday
Got up & had breakfast at usual time - very cold last night with some snow - Woke up with the cold, had also a little touch of breast pang & earache _ but soon got over all of them.
Am Presdt of a Genl Court Martial convinced

thought. He did not leave until I was called to dinner at 3½ pm. Today has been very pleasant clear but cold - but it has clouded up again tonight & the wind blows sharply - Townsend & the Infy got in today & are camped just above us - Mackenzie moved down the river a few miles for grass.
Whist at night & got beaten soundly - wretched hands -

Belle Fourche
Decr 14, 1876
Thursday -
Got up & had breakfast at usual time.  Very cold last night with some snow - Woke up with the cold had also a little touch of breastpang & earache - but soon got over all of them.
Am Presdt of a Genl Court Martial Convened

to try a young Officer of Mackenzies Comd named Otis. The offence amounts to but little & Mack had much better have given the boy a good scolding or a weeks arrest. It is absurd to my Officers for every little Offence - It only hardens them & renders them careless of any shame of being before a court -

good result to me.
Belle Fourche
Decr 15 - 76
Out of bed & breakfast late.
At half past ten went over to Hdqrs for Court Martial 
Found every body excited over arrival of Suttler with 5 barrels of whiskey - which though a good thing is likely to do us damage -
Court met about 11 am The accused slower than a turtle - Had to

The day has been delightful cool clear & bracing. No zeros. Indian Scouts not yet heard from - I mean those from Agency - The spies not yet in. Not a pound of grain on hand & less than a weeks rations - We are looking anxiously for the train.
It ought to be here on 16th I think our expedition draws to a close - without any good result to me.

to buy whatever their men needed - I shall try hard to keep my men sober, but am doubtful if I succeed - 
Came back to my tent & soon after Genl Crook came over to pay me a visit. He was very affable & chatted quite freely, though I could see that his object in coming was that I should not be too stringent

bully him finally or we would never have gotten through
Closed his defense about 12 m. & then Court adjourned til tomorrow 11 am - By this time the Suttler had his tent pitched - I went over to see him & soon after issued orders prohibiting the sale of liquor by drink or quantity to any enlisted man but authorizing Compy Comdrs

unclear at an end -
He is waiting for his spies & for his scouts - also for the supplies - but if the first two do not come in a day or two, or do not report favorably, I think he will return -
We are all satisfied that nothing further can be done & therefore are all anxious to go back as soon

on the Suttler. However he gave me considerable information. Randal has arrived at Reno with 76 Crows - but has to wait there a few days to recuperate. The 23d Infy is ordered to Dep of Missouri & I am more than pleased.
Crook says that many trails of Indians with travois are passing South towards the Agency. & he thinks the

papers - I got nothing except one Official letter - Had my case filled with whiskey this afternoon - & am now set up - A nice game of whist at night & got beat - Had a good bath -
Weather very threatening - not cold but looks like a bad snow storm - 
To bed rather late -

as possible - Were there any hope of striking the hostiles I would say "go on" particularly as we poor Doboys have so far had no show but if we cant strike there is no sort of use in our staying out here - losing horses & mules, & suffering ourselves without necessity -- 

A mail came by scout today - but principally

any quantity of venison flying about - as regards the forage coming up on the train - In the first place the train is a day or two behind time & it is said that it has no forage - that it will arrive without a pound We are now entirely out & if no more is coming we should leave for Ft Fetterman at once.




any quantity of venison flying about - as regards the forage coming up on the train - In the first place the train is a day or two behind time & it is said that it has no forage - that it will arrive without a pound We are now entirely out & if no more is coming we should leave for Ft Fetterman at once.

Belle Fourche
Dec 16, 76
Up late for Camp life.
Went over to Hdqrs at Court time - Soon disposed of the Lieutenant & afterwards of 3 other cases enlisted men.
Adjourned six O'cl & told Boarke that if he gave us another case I would sit on him - so I guess we wont have any more.

after dark however the long threatened storm set in & it has been snowing fast for some hours - 
There seems to be a sort of hold up now, but it may be bad or good tomorro 
It is getting too late in the season to fool with the weather & I shall urge the Genl to go back at once -
unless he has some pretty sure hope of striking a hostile camp or force

We can't do a thing without forage - If a storm such as may be now expected should now strike us we may lose from starvation & cold half our stock If we go in when forage & stabling care be had, every every animal within  two months be in condition for another expedition.
I must go over tomorro & see the Genl about our prospects. The day has been cold & blustery, tho not stormy

unclear - everybody in a greater state of doubt than ever as to what will be next move. No president yet! -
Trouble with the whiskey mill of course but have got it on a pretty good basis -
Several visitors at night & sat up late -

Belle Fourche
Decr 17, 76
Up late as usual - Went over to Hdqrs but did not see the Genl - Jordan arrived with a train of 80 wagons - 128,000 lbs forage - 12 days half rations - a paper mail came also but no

The wagons yesterday brought ½ forage for 12 days  & rations to about the 15th January. It is said there is another train now nearly due with ½ forage for 10 days more. So with the new outfit our stay in the wilderness is getting more uncertain every day. I thought two days

Belle Fourche
Decr 18 - 76
Up late as usual -
Mack over to see General Crook in morning -
Met Mackenzie there
Had a long & very pleasant visit. There is nothing new. The expected Indians have not arrived & the Genl

our increased stock of supplies Randall was at Ft Reno at last accounts with 76 Crow Indians. He is expected daily - No one knows what are the plans of Genl C. I don't believe he has any. but expects to make up his mind when he gets further information. He is a regular bull dog to hold on & will not quit unless forced to.

ago that we would probably start on our return for Ft Fetterman by the 20th  now it is scarcely probable that we will get back there much before 10 Jany

 If we can do anything I shall be very glad but the prospects are that the hostiles have decamped to beyond where we can

containing a good deal of news - The political situation is the same - Hayes Elected, but as the Dutchman said by a "train tight squeeze" of a couple of votes & an impending contest when the votes come to be counted.

 Brooklyn theatre burned -
 Horrible catastrophe --
 Harder Infy dead & some small fry resigned or dead
 But the best news of all is the certainty of my

Belle Fourche
Decr 19 76
Up at usual time to find on my breakfast table 4 letters, one from Father another from Kate Chambless - all containing good very good news. A courier got in during the night with a bundle of letters & telegrams

Randal Wheaton & Pollock will likely all go to Leavenworth as soon as this Expn is over. 
I dont know where I will go. My choice Ft Lyon is occupied by a Col. Smith of 19th -
I will therefore have most likely Riley Gibson or Dodge
I wrote to Bob Williams last night asking him to write to Pope for me & give me Riley or Gibson as would be better for

Rgt leaving this Dept for Kansas or Dep of Platte Hdqrs left or more to leave on 13th. Hinton has gone to Ft Dodge. Hascall to Ft Riley. Smith to Ft Leavenworth E Kridge is ordered to Gibson. Coffinger & Brady to Reno (the Arrapahoe Agency) Nickerson Co. Goodale Comd goes also but I dont know to what

camp. Have to unclear a long march. Dodge read me part of a letter from his wife: about the move. Wrote to Joe & Laura giving directions.

 Wrote also to Potter & a long letter to Father & Mother.
 Indians have not arrived & we are all getting decidedly impatient. It is dread? fully irksome to be on such a campaign & doing nothing.

Tooty. Either would be satisfactory to me, but I want that which suit the health & taste of the "old Lady". 

 The G. C. M. of which I am Presdt was ordered to meet again today for trial of a couple of cavalry soldiers. Got through with them. The move tomorro a short distance down the river. Am very glad of it for it is far more tedious lying in

Randal sent a scout to us last night. He will be along in a day or two. 

But our trouble now is that the expected Indians from the agencies & the spies all of whom ought to be here.
have not only not arrived but not a word has been heard from them

Got with camp before 10 am -

Belle Fourche
Decr 20 76
Reveille at 5.30 - Townsend late - says he got no orders -
Broke camp 7.- Stopped for nearly an hour at Mackenzies. Genl C. was there. He is mad about his Indians & says that somebody ought to be hung. He will stick it out on this river, until

about can thus always be known he allows to keep arms & ponies. Those who he cannot rely on he disarms & dismounts. He thinks that Mason would not dare to go so decidedly against his wishes & plans, unless he had orders to do so from Sheridan. If S. has given the order it nullifies all that Crook has done & stops at once any further

The general is in a terrible humor. The news brought him last night is to the effect that Mason - at Red Cloud is discovering all the Indians friendly as well as hostile -
Crooks place is to make a wide & marked distinction between these classes --
Those Indians who obey his orders - Submit to be counted & attend all

Sheridan will ever know & it is very hard after working so long & indefatigably to get things in shape to have all overturned in a moment.

 We lie over here tomorro - & there is no telling what effect the news is going to have on the final result of the expn
 Snow last night but lovely clear & bright today -
 Distance 6 miles -
 Frank White - Chief of

progress in his plans for the future - This taken with the absence of all information in regard to his spies? has completely knocked? the "old man" up. He told me that he did not sleep a wink last night & pretended that he is sick. He is really only worried - I dont blame him for being disgusted - He knows more about the

to Maj North - He says the Sioux yesterday gave the Pawnees a grand begging dance in which the latter were badly flawed it being regarded as a mark of great meanness not to give something on such occasions.

 The wily Sioux secured 50 or 60 horses & a great many other valuable things. Frank gave

Pawnees came over to call on me this afternoon & brought me a small portion of the scalp of Dull Knife's youngest son, who was killed by the Pawnees in the affair of Mackenzies - It is the very greatest compliment in his estimation that he could pay me & almost makes us brothers - I went over to the Pawnee Camp

of the Deity in vain, offer sacrifices & set aside certain things as consecrated to Him.
Some old plug of a horse will be offered to the Gr Spirit by some devout individual - After that the horse is taken the best care of is never ridden nor even bridled never struck by a whip & is regarded as sacred by all

3 horses & a suit of finery. North gave some interesting facts in regard to the Pawnee religion. They believe in one God from whom comes all good & all bad. They are fatalists & accept every thing as His will without murmur or cavil. They are very religious - have no oaths in their language never take the name

more careful of the exposure of their persons & do not sell the persons of their unclear. Men & women are all loose if opportunity serves, but take great pains not to be caught - They are extremely superstitious & most of their actions are determined by signs & omens. 

 Frank says they never wish to go on the war path again but to go to farming & raising stock

In ceremonial smokes they emit two puffs upward to the Great Spirit & one downward to the Earth, which is called the bastion? of the dead. They do not believe in a Bad Good or Devil. They are excessively feisty personally, but have more regard to what we call the decencies? of life than the Cheyennes. They are

stove - The easiest managed stove if one understands it. The most refractory if one does'nt - Got up late & had a chilly uncomfortable breakfast - A Drunken Cavalry man frozen last night

Many visitors in the morning, all anxious to know what we are going to do - to which conundrum there is no answer --
 It now appears that the train which was to bring in supplies

Belle Fourche
Decr 21 1876
A bad storm came on in the night with snow & wind. Very cold - My stove pipe would not draw, & I was waked up by a tent so full of smoke that I could not see across it. My man is a first class Dutchman willing & obedient, but so stupid. He has never yet been able to learn how

On the road I met MacKenzie just coming in to Camp told him that C was down in the mouth  & that he had better come over to my tent -- "That is the more reason for our going to see him" said he. Lets go & give him some consolation & propose a game of whist." I could

has gone on to Reno & left the supplies there. We have now only to 2nd Jany & must decide on something  very soon. Having written this much I strolled over to Hdqrs. Saw the Genl a moment but he looked so disconsolate & preoccupied that I had not the courage to tackle him - Went into Bouskys tent & gassed with him for some time, then

said the old man - I have got to have a big Indian Council today & it is nearly time.

The fact is "continued he after a pause "I have made up my mind to turn back tomorro & want to give the Indians a good talk & let them go direct to their Resn"
 He then went on to tell

hardly keep from smiling at this for they were almost the identical words used by Crook to me when I told him how downhearted he always was after his fight --
Of course I agreed & we went in to the Genl's tent.

After the first greetings Mac proposed the game "I cant play today"

& in our depleted condition as to rations & forage & with our animals so reduced in flesh & strength.

 Mackenzie & I both agreed with him both asserted our willingness to stick as long as there was a hope - but that hope being now past the first consideration was our men & animals.

us of the difficulties which beset him - the apparent impossibility of finding out exactly where the hostile camp is. The failure of his spies to report, proving that the position of that camp is very distant from us - the folly of attempting to scout in search of it in the vast country in which the hostiles roam

there was no chance
I thought the best thing to do was to put the men & animals in good quarters as soon as possible

 They were not so much run down now but that two months of care & good feed would not put them in condition to take the field again.

While if we waited until they were quite

Mac said it was not his responsibility but that he had thought for a week past that it would be best to return. I said that I would probably gain more by a successful campaign than either of them & that my disposition was to stick as long as there was a chance - that as it was now conceded

are very jolly & have been dancing singing & tom toming ever since I dont believe there is a man in the crowd who is not happier for the order

I wrote several letters to go by the courier. & sent those I had previously written - Tooty Father & Mother. Kate Chambless Bob William, Potter  & Joe & Laura

broken down he would not only lose many but the others would not be recuperated in time for a Campaign next spring.

 So after an hours talk I came away to give the order for the move to the rear -- The Indians went up to Hdqrs soon after were talked to & are to start toorro

Campbell visited me at night & we had an "old Army" talk - scandal reminiscences and unclear & stories of all kinds very badly mixed with sundry drinks of whiskey.

The order to move to the rear did not come until after unclear -
Been snowing all day & getting worse tonight

I had already written one to Father & Mother so wrote another with the good news -

 Mackenzie came in just after dinner & we had a good talk. He is annoyed that he did not do better with the chances he had, yet pleased that he did so well, & that we all

Reveille at 5.30. Broke Camp at 7.10 - It was snowing when we started, but by 9 oclk held up & tried to be good - Could'nt make it however, & soon after got worse rapidly - By 11 am we were enjoying a most terrific norther - Snow wind & cold combined - I halted my Comd every little while & made them wait the arrival of our wagons

Belle Fourche
Friday Dec 22 76
I started on this expedition on Friday. I start on my return on Friday - My little wife would be worried at such flying in the face of the Ancient Superstition but Friday has always been a very lucky day to me except in minor discomforts

the frozen ground as difficult to get footing on as the smoothest sheet of ice.

Every little pitch had to be dug down not because it was too steep but simply to give footing to the mules.
 In some places the road had to be picked & cut with axes for many yards. By 4 pm the wagons of my Comd were all in - Genl C. had selected the site

for I have no notion of a separation from those useful receptacles? in such weather - About 1 pm I overtook Genl Crook - ensconced in a nook under high bluffs & here the camp was made. The road was terribly bad. Some had crossings & steep pitches but bad even at the best places from being covered with ice, which made

5° This was in our little sheltered nook. I have no doubt that was at least -5° on the plain on top of the bluff over which we had just come - Several of the Officers & men had their noses & ears frozen. Altogether it has been anything but a lovely day & if we had to face the storm instead of going before it, we must

for his Hdqr tents - gave me a very small space for my Comd & apparently overlooked  a sweet little cove just at the foot of a high bluff unclear with trees & bushes all around - I seized upon that immediately for my Hdqrs & have the very best position of all - While waiting for the wagons we put out a thermometer & found that it indicated

snowing quite fast. There is every prospect of a similar day tomorro for which I propose to be better prepared - We are rather short of wood tonight but for at least two camps ahead there is none - We must take from here enough to keep us from freezing. 
This is the 2° day of the storm - Tomorrow ought

have lost many men.

I did not suffer very greatly though several times I thought I ought to stop & don my leggins & other storm defiers but I stuck it out. My fingers & toes suffered but I got to camp all right. The Ther went down to 0 about 6 pm but after that it moderated a little. It is

carry besides 50 days half forage for the animals

Why it did not I have discovered 
The qr mr Dept - Wagon Masters Teamsters etc - carry bedding enough for 40 companies - unclear tents for 50 companies 
 Sibley Stoves for 20 companies & 44 cooking stoves of which there are only 2 unclear in the whole Comd Genl C's men & Maj Townsend's men
 In other words the Citizens

to be the last - I am truly glad we are going back for such weather must have broken up our organization & killed off our accumulation a few days more -

 I have been summing up today some of the causes of Crooks failure - I find on calculation that our transfer ought to carry 60 days rations for the whole Comd give 2 wagons to each compy

are broken down not so much by their work, as by punitive neglect - The teamsters tie the mules to the wagon tongue when they get into camp, put some corn in the feed trough & some cotton wood under the tongue then go off to their tents with the supply train -

In the morning they get to their teams barely in time to hitch up & pull out & the mules get nothing to eat in the morning.

employees of the Qm Dept carry more impediments? than would be required by a force? of troops nearly double what we have. There are 27 Co-- Troops including the Co Hdqr Gd - These Citizens carry the baggage of at least 45 Comps - Besides this the Citizens are unclear in no sort of discipline & do just as they please - Our mules

down from hard work when they are neglected & starved. His successes must always be accidents as was this last - & he must fail because he cannot himself organize & has not the judgment to select men who can - He is brave tenacious & the best judge of Indian Character in the Army - but he lacks -- 

Distances today 13 miles

Yet Genl C. insists that Fury is a most excellent qrtmr & that he could not get along without him - Crooks gridlock is organization - He knows nothing about it & is obliged to trust to others. He asks no questions & believes what is said to him - He gives no orders - Examining with no details - He is told he can carry only certain stoves & does his best on that
